docs.lead_paragraph: One interesting comment on last week's post about proposed employer mandates for health care coverage came from someone who called herself "AnnS." AnnS seemed to know a lot about health insurance decision-making, and she led us through the calculation that one low-wage firm, apparently a regional convenience store chain, would make if faced with an employer mandate. AnnS is pessimistic. "Employers like this - who have a large number of uninsured low-wage workers - WILL NOT provide those workers with coverage and WILL BE motivated to drop coverage for the lower-ranking employees who do have coverage," she wrote.

headline.main: Counterpoint: How a Mandate Could Cost Employees Their Company Insurance

docs.abstract: Employers who have a large number of uninsured low wage workers may be motivated to drop coverage for the lower-ranking employees who do have coverage.
docs.snippet: Employers who have a large number of uninsured low wage workers may be motivated to drop coverage for the lower-ranking employees who do have coverage.

docs.lead_paragraph: On the heels of Friday's job report showing unemployment at a quarter-century high, President Obama and Congressional Democrats are examining a range of ideas in their attempts to spark job creation.
docs.abstract: Looking for job growth; troop levels in Afghanistan; health care legislation on pause.
docs.snippet: Looking for job growth; troop levels in Afghanistan; health care legislation on pause.

docs.lead_paragraph: Insurance exchanges -- or marketplaces -- are the fallback position for every health care bill now pending in Congress. Whatever the other particulars, all the bills assume that small employers and individuals will be able to find more insurance options, at more affordable prices, through creation of exchanges in which insurers compete for their businesses.
docs.abstract: Policy experts and a Texas businessman explain how an "insurance exchange" could prove be better in theory than in practice.
docs.snippet: Policy experts and a Texas businessman explain how an "insurance exchange" could prove be better in theory than in practice.
